title: Sick of Trump news? I’m here for you
summary: This is a good time to take a step back from the circus and read some broader reflections on life.

title: The rise of right-wing nihilism
summary: The acidic core of nihilism is the loss of faith in the values your culture tells you to believe in. And it's a cultural river that leads nowhere good.

title: How tariffs destroy what makes America great
summary: Trump is building walls. His trade policies obstruct not only the flow of goods but also the flow of ideas, contacts, technology and friendships as well.

title: We deserve Pete Hegseth
summary: The lesson for Democrats over the next four years is clear: Don’t fly into moral outrage every day. Focus on Trumpian incompetence.

title: Voters to elites: Do you see me now?
summary: Schools are not set up for male success; that has lifelong personal, and now national, consequences.

title: How Trump wins (and Harris and the Democrats blow it)
summary: Columnist David Brooks considers what strategy former President Donald Trump might use to be re-elected to the presidency.

title: We haven’t hit peak populism yet
summary: Populists promise to tear down systems. Liberals need to make the case for changing them in a comprehensive and constructive way.

title: In dispiriting times, turning to the wisdom of Churchill and Roosevelt
summary: We need a leader who can counteract former President Donald Trump’s sour and grievance-ridden patriotism with a vaster and more generous patriotism.

title: The fight for the soul of AI
summary: Can one organization, or one person, maintain the brain of a scientist, the drive of a capitalist and the cautious heart of a regulatory agency?

title: Nikki Haley is the best Trump alternative
summary: At the GOP presidential debate, Haley seemed to look at the Trump/Ramaswamy wing and implicitly say: You children need to stop preening and deal with reality.

title: What if anti-Trumpers are the bad guys?
summary: Most of us in the educated class are earnest, kind and public spirited. But we take for granted and benefit from systems that have become oppressive.

title: Third-party candidate? Not now
summary: This is not the time to be running risky experiments, the outcomes of which none of us can foresee.

title: Let’s smash the college admissions process
summary: The elite meritocracy has spiraled out of control.

title: The power of American capitalism
summary: We’ve lived through a wretched political era. The social fabric is fraying in a thousand ways. But American capitalism rolls on.

title: Moving toward a red-blue mash-up
summary: We know the policy mix that creates a dynamic society. We just don’t yet have a party that wants to promote it.

title: The power of art in a political age
summary: Art teaches you to see the world through the eyes of another, often a person who sees more deeply than you do.

title: Let’s all do the DeSantis shimmy!
summary: As the presidential campaign wears on, and the debate on Ukraine continues, DeSantis will be condemned to playing Mini-Me to Donald Trump.

title: Revolutionize American schools
summary: This moment of disruption should be a moment of reinvention. But there is a complete absence of leadership.

title: The sad tales of George Santos
summary: The U.S. representative-elect from New York is a young man who apparently felt compelled to jettison much of his actual life and replace it with fantasy.

title: Confessions of a middle-aged fanboy
summary: I suppose I listen to the music for the energy, for the fun, and because it’s a place I can go and not hear opinions on the threat of authoritarian populism.

title: Performative populism, be gone!
summary: Voters have built a wall around the MAGA movement to make sure it no longer wins the power it once enjoyed.

title: Democrats' working-class problem
summary: Animosity fueled by a class divide has left the electoral balance on a razor’s edge.

title: Why Republicans are surging
summary: GOP candidates are telling a very clear class/culture/status war narrative in which common-sense Americans are being assaulted by elite progressives.

title: The triumph of the Ukrainian idea
summary: Ukraine’s tenacity shows how powerful liberal nationalism can be in the face of an authoritarian threat.

title: Take off your earbuds and talk to a stranger — it's good for you
summary: Once you get used to filling your day with social exercise, it gets easier and easier, and more and more fun.

title: The greatest life hacks in the world (for now)
summary: How to find serenity through life hacks

title: Cancel student debt — for some
summary: I’m hoping President Joe Biden will limit the forgiveness to precarity grads — perhaps to those from families making less than $75,000.

title: Finding equilibrium after loss
summary: After loss, many people make a moral leap: I may never understand what happened, but I can be more understanding toward others.

title: How to be aggressively friendly
summary: Our happiness, as well as our health and fulfillment, is hugely dependent on our ability to be skillfully understanding of and considerate toward others.

title: Getting inside Putin's head
summary: Putin invaded Ukraine so Russians could feel that they are a great nation once again and so Putin himself could feel that he’s a world historical figure.

title: What can you say to someone in pain?
summary: We all need witnesses — to witness others, to be witnessed, to draw inspiration from each other. “Consolation is an act of solidarity in space,” Michael Ignatieff wrote in his new book, “On Consolation.”

title: Integration without assimilation
summary: It is the only way forward. It is, as the prophet Jeremiah suggested, to transmit the richness of your own cultures while seeking the peace and prosperity of the city to which you have been carried.

title: The battle of subcultures
summary: If you want to stage a radical critique of individualism and intellectual rigor, be my guest, but things get problematic when you assign the “good” side of this tension to one racial category and the “bad” side to another racial category.

title: The triumph of the scorned
summary: Much of the drive and dynamism of American life comes from humiliated people saying, “We’ll show them who we are.”

title: Moderates and progressives, unite!
summary: Covid has exposed the tears in the American social fabric and made Americans more enthusiastic about government spending.
